docs.snippet: Human rights abuses in Guatemala have become ''particularly intractable,'' according to a report issued last week by a New York-based organization.   The group, Americas Watch, concluded in a 260-page report that killings and disappearances of civ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Human rights abuses in Guatemala have become ''particularly intractable,'' according to a report issued last week by a New York-based organization. The group, Americas Watch, concluded in a 260-page report that killings and disappearances of civilians in the cities had increased in the five months since Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores took power in a coup that ousted Gen. Efrain Rios Montt. The report, the result of a seven- month investigation, added that the Reagan Administration ''shares in the responsibility for the gross abuses of human rights'' by failing to publicly denounce them.

headline.main: RIGHTS GROUP SAYS ABUSES IN GUATEMALA RISE

docs.snippet: A h, the Celtic Irish and, ah, the Anglo-Saxon English - for centuries they have been glowering at each other, if not worse, and producing some of the best literature in the language common to them both. The Anglo- Irish list of great writers rang...
docs.lead_paragraph: A h, the Celtic Irish and, ah, the Anglo-Saxon English - for centuries they have been glowering at each other, if not worse, and producing some of the best literature in the language common to them both. The Anglo- Irish list of great writers ranges, just to mention a few of the more outstanding examples, from Jonathan Swift to Richard Brinsley Sheridan to Oscar Wilde. Oddly enough, the confrontation of the two cultures, long saturated in tragedy, has produced a rather startling amount of comedy. A Sean O'Casey might excel in the tricky genre of tragicomedy, but other writers, those like Honor Tracy, have developed a humorous style of a wickedly clever sort. In this latter category are two somewhat eccentric cousins, Edith Somerville and Violet Florence Martin, whose nom de plume was Martin Ross. The two began collaborating on literary ventures in the final decades of the last century. One of their works, ''Some Experiences of an Irish R. M.,'' has been adapted for television by a consortium of British and Irish organizations and, beginning tonight at 9 on WNET/Channel 13, will be running on public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' for the next six weeks. Not surprisingly, the series has its devilishly hilarious moments.

headline.main: WICKED IRISH WIT ENLIVENS A NEW MINI-SERIES

docs.snippet: 'CANTORIAL' OPENING     A young couple troubled by mysterious events occurring in the Manhattan loft into which they have just moved is the substance of Ira Levin's new play ''Cantorial,'' opening at the Hartman Theater in Stamford Friday.   Bille...
docs.lead_paragraph: 'CANTORIAL' OPENING A young couple troubled by mysterious events occurring in the Manhattan loft into which they have just moved is the substance of Ira Levin's new play ''Cantorial,'' opening at the Hartman Theater in Stamford Friday. Billed as a comedy-drama, the production is the first theater work by Mr. Levin since ''Deathtrap,'' the thriller that ran on Broadway from 1978 to 1982 and was made into a movie starring Michael Caine and Christopher Reeve. Some of Mr. Levin's other successes as novels, plays and films include ''Rosemary's Baby,'' ''The Stepford Wives,'' ''The Boys From Brazil'' and ''Critic's Choice.'' The cast of seven includes Kristoffer Tabori, son of the actress Viveca Lindfors, as the young husband. Marjorie Bradley Kellogg and Ann Roth are responsible for the sets and costumes, respectively, and Edwin Sherin, artistic director of the theater, is directing.

docs.snippet: During his 16 seasons as a head coach, Red Auerbach was noted for baiting referees. So it was a familar scene today when the 66-year-old president and general manager of the Boston Celtics became enraged at the officiating in the National Basketba...
docs.lead_paragraph: During his 16 seasons as a head coach, Red Auerbach was noted for baiting referees. So it was a familar scene today when the 66-year-old president and general manager of the Boston Celtics became enraged at the officiating in the National Basketball Association's first old-timers' game. Auerbach, coaching the East in the game that involved some of the greatest names in league history, staged some play-acting with Sid Borgia, one of the two officials and an old adversary, for the standing-room crowd of 17,251 at McNichols Arena. But he was not acting as he fumed at Norm Drucker, the other official, after the East had lost to the West, 65-63.

headline.main: Auerbach Fumes as N.B.A. West Old-Timers Win

docs.snippet: A Guatemalan security officer said today that the military Government foiled a planned coup this month in which a group of retired generals hired an assassin in Miami to kill the chief of state, Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores.   A Guatemalan Army press...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Guatemalan security officer said today that the military Government foiled a planned coup this month in which a group of retired generals hired an assassin in Miami to kill the chief of state, Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores. A Guatemalan Army press spokesman, Edgar Djalma Dominguez, declined to comment on the report. The security official said in an interview that the generals, who had been forced to retire by a new military law, met in mid-January at a hotel in a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to plan General Mejia Victores's overthrow. The official said they withdrew money from Miami bank accounts to hire a killer and bribe top military commanders to join the plot.

docs.snippet: News   Analysis    Many of its 850 pages are filled with traffic studies, maps and pollution estimates. But at its heart, the environmental impact statement for the proposed Times Square redevelopment project is an impassioned battle plan.  Its go...
docs.lead_paragraph: News Analysis Many of its 850 pages are filled with traffic studies, maps and pollution estimates. But at its heart, the environmental impact statement for the proposed Times Square redevelopment project is an impassioned battle plan. Its goal is to reclaim Manhattan's most centrally situated block - 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues - from the crime and tawdriness that have made it off-limits to so many New Yorkers. Its strategy results from fundamental changes in planning policy over two decades that place a premium on an amenity overlooked through years of urban renewal and midtown office development - the city's vibrant, quirky and overflowing street life.

docs.snippet: Dancing, tumbling, twirling, standing on their heads, ''popping'' their joints, young people around the nation are doing ''the break.''    The break, an acrobatic blend of gymnastics, ballet, martial arts and pantomime that originated in the pover...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dancing, tumbling, twirling, standing on their heads, ''popping'' their joints, young people around the nation are doing ''the break.'' The break, an acrobatic blend of gymnastics, ballet, martial arts and pantomime that originated in the poverty of Harlem and the South Bronx a decade ago, has moved out of the ghetto. From Boston to San Francisco, young people are spending hours a day practicing headstands, handstands and somersaults and performing on sidewalks in shopping malls, gymnasiums and on public stages. So many break dancers perform each weekend in Westwood Village, a college neighborhood on the west side of Los Angeles, that police officers have been called to clear the streets of spectators. More than 160 young people were sent home from Westwood one recent weekend after merchants complained and the police cited them for violating the city's anti-loitering law.

headline.main: DANCING IN THE STREETS WITH A DREAM

docs.snippet: The General Foods Corporation said yesterday that net income in its third quarter, ended Dec. 31, climbed 30.5 percent, to $66.7 million, or $1.28 a share, from $51.1 million, or $1 a share, a year earlier. Sales edged up 5 percent, to $2.1 billio...
docs.lead_paragraph: The General Foods Corporation said yesterday that net income in its third quarter, ended Dec. 31, climbed 30.5 percent, to $66.7 million, or $1.28 a share, from $51.1 million, or $1 a share, a year earlier. Sales edged up 5 percent, to $2.1 billion, from $2 billion. The White Plains company attributed the improved results to sales gains in most of its businesses, including ''healthy contributions'' from its Oscar Mayer & Company meat product unit and its Entenmann's baked goods subsidiary.

docs.snippet: Nominations were announced today for the 1983 Directors Guild of America award, an award which usually foreshadows the outcome of the Oscars.   This year's guild nominees are Bruce Beresford for ''Tender Mercies,'' the story of the redemption of a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nominations were announced today for the 1983 Directors Guild of America award, an award which usually foreshadows the outcome of the Oscars. This year's guild nominees are Bruce Beresford for ''Tender Mercies,'' the story of the redemption of a country-western singer; Ingmar Bergman for ''Fanny and Alexander,'' a rich, loving look at the Sweden of his childhood; James L. Brooks for ''Terms of Endearment,'' a comedy that turns tragic as it follows the relationship of a mother and daughter; Lawrence Kasdan for ''The Big Chill,'' a comedy about a group of college friends, and Philip Kaufman for ''The Right Stuff,'' the history of the first seven astronauts and the legendary test pilot Chuck Yeager.
